moves.3... Nf6: I can now play Ng5 (Fried Liver Attack)
moves.5. exd5 Nxd5 6. Nxf7: An attacking move. After 6. Kxf7 7. Qf3+ threatening knight on d5.
moves.6... Kxf7 7. Qf3+ Ke8: (?) King goes straight back to his normal square.
moves.12. d3: Blocking c2, probably the best move.
moves.12... Ke7: (?) I didn't, don't and don't think ever will understand this move.
moves.13. a3: Getting rid of the annoying knight.
moves.13... Nc6 14. Nd5+: (!) Winning free pawn on f6. If: 14. Kf7? Nxc7+! winning rook. It works the same if black plays Ke6.
moves.16. Nd5 Nd4: Threatening my bishop, who is protecting my knight.
moves.17... Kxe7 18. Kd2: Probably the best move. If I had played Ba4, this is what would have happened… 18. b5 19. Bb3 Nxb3 20. cxb3 Bxd3 (winning free pawn)
moves.18... Nxb3+: A swap that I don't usually like, especially when it doubles my pawns.
moves.22. f3: Blocking mate and threatening the bishop.
moves.25... Rb3 26. Rf2: If I had left my rook on f1, Bd3+ pretty much wins the game.
moves.27. Ke1 Bc4: Good move, now my pawn on f3 is almost lost. It stops me from playing Ke2.
moves.28. Rc2: A skewer, winning pawn after Bb5.
moves.29. a4: (!) Threatening the protector of the bishop.
moves.29... a6 30. Rc3 Rxc3 31. bxc3 Rxf3: The game is now equal, but black has an advantage position wise.
moves.38... Bxd3 39. Kf2 Kf6: Both kings wanting to get into each other's territory.
moves.40. h4: The f, g and h files are al blocked for the black king.
moves.40... e4 41. Ke3 Ke5 42. Bd4+ Kd5 43. h5: My only hope is to go for the queen.
moves.44... Kxb4 45. g6 hxg6: (??????) Loses, after my opponent made this move, I muttered softly, yes!
moves.46. h6: (!) gets the queen. After hxg6, then black plays Bc4, and my queening square is controlled by the bishop.
moves.46... c5 47. Bxc5+: Don't ask me why I suicided, I was just excited about getting a queen.
moves.50... Kb4 51. Qxg4 a5 52. Qd1 a4: I must stop black from queening.
moves.55. Qc3+: My phone rings and I lose the game. I just said I won it on this annotated game because I only a few moves away from mate. Anyway, the moral is: never bring your mobile phone to a chess tournament!

opening: two knights defence (C57), Fegatello attack, Leonhardt variation
